awd_titl_txt: Novel Electrophilic Carbene Architectures and Related Main Group Analogs
awd_abstract_narration:
Carbon is the building material upon which the elements of life are constructed. A basic tenet is that carbon forms four chemical bonds. In this project, funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Todd Hudnall of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at Texas State University - San Marcos seeks to prepare substances that violate the four-bonds per carbon principle. Specifically, compounds called carbenes that contain carbon with only two bonds are prepared. Because of the unusually low number of bonds, carbenes are very reactive and have important electronic properties. The methods that are developed to prepare the carbenes are extended to the related elements, germanium and tin. These synthetic methods potentially useful, low temperature ways to access metastable alloys. In addition to training undergraduate and graduate students, this project may ultimately result in the discovery of novel materials that may benefit society in applications ranging from quantum computing to single molecular magnets to catalysts.  Professor Hudnall has maintained a collaborative outreach program with the McKenna Children’s Museum called “Laboratory Workstations.” This program engages children, ages 3-10, in hands-on simple chemistry experiments in mock gloveboxes, and is also inclusive of local chemistry students from Canyon High School. Texas State University is an Hispanic Serving Institution.  This project provides research experiences to students from groups underrepresented in science. 

The aim of this project is to prepare electrophilic carbene ligands and related main group analogs. Sets of carbenes, whose electrophilic character and attendant pi-acidity can be systematically increased by a lowering of their respective Lowest Unoccupied Molecular Orbital (LUMO) energy levels, are targeted using computations. These compounds and related germanium and tin species with exceptionally small singlet-triplet gaps are prepared. Among these are diamidosilylenes, germylenes, stannylenes, and cationic heterocyclic carbenes. One question that is investigated is why diamidocarbenes can be photolyzed to a triplet excited state where other carbenes cannot. The photochemistry of the carbenes is explored and applications as electrophilic carbene-supported main group catalysts and as precursors for the low-temperature generation of main group alloys are developed. The program serves students from underrepresented groups by their inclusion in the research project and though outreach programs to K-12 students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
During the course of his work the project entitled, “Novel Electrophilic Carbene Architectures and Related Main Group Analogs” Prof. Todd Hudnall’s group continued their work on the design and synthesis of pi-acidic carbene ligands. Specifically, Hudnall prepared alpha-imino-functionalized cyclic diamidocarbenes, indole-derived carbenes, and cyclic(aryl)amido carbenes, the latter of which represents the most pi-acidic carbenes reported to date. Hudnall and his group also demonstrated that the catalytic activity of main group elements can be enhanced by coordination of the pi-acidic carbenes they developed. This discovery has led to a new research project focused on main group element catalysis.  Previously, Hudnall found that one of the pi-acidic carbenes, namely a diamidocarbene (DAC), is photochemically active, and can undergo photoswitching from the singlet ground state to a triplet excited state, enabling new photochemical reactivities.  As an extension of the last part of this work, Hudnall more recently demonstrated that DACs can activate inert C-H bonds of simple alkanes when irradiated at 380 nm. This opens new avenues for the functionalization of hydrocarbons, an area Hudnall will continue to explore moving forward. The results obtained throughout the course of this project mark an important contribution to science, technology, and the public at large because they provide new fundamental structure-reactivity relationships in carbene chemistry which has far-reaching applications in areas such as renewable energy and materials science. 

Prof. Hudnall’s lead of this project had much broader impacts beyond the work completed in his lab which resulted in the publication of 4 peer-reviewed manuscripts, with another 2 currently in preparation for submission later in 2024. This project also supported the education and professional development of 5 graduate students, 1 Ph.D. and 4 M.S. students, 15 undergraduate students, and 2 postdoctoral researchers. Indeed, 10 of these students have now gone on to pursue doctoral studies at prestigious institutions such as Texas A&M University, UT Austin, UC Davis, Colorado, and Michigan. Beyond the professional development of students and postdocs, this project allowed Prof. Hudnall to provide outreach programs to local K-12 students. Hudnall also organized several sessions and symposia at the regional/national ACS meetings where his students presented their results including: the main group chemistry and earth abundant metals catalysis sessions at the National ACS meetings, a special topics symposium entitled, Main Group Chemistry in the Southwest, held at the 2021 Southwest Regional ACS meeting in Austin, TX, and the award symposium for the Harry Gray Award for Creative Inorganic Chemistry in honor of Dr. Robert Gilliard, which was held at the 2023 spring National ACS meeting in Indianapolis. Hundall's research group has primarily assisted in local outreach activities including the ACS WISE conference, the STEM communities workshops and the newly established NSF PREM CIMA program at Texas State.

In sum, this project was a very fruitful and rewarding experience for Prof. Hudnall, his students, and the community at large. The scientific findings supported by this grant represent significant contributions to the field of chemistry and to the broader scientific community at large, and lay the foundation for future discovery.


Last Modified: 10/07/2024
Modified by: Todd W Hudnall
